title: 107_hr389
content: The "Family Building Act of 2001" acknowledges infertility as a disease affecting millions of Americans and highlights the lack of coverage for infertility therapy in group health plans. The Act aims to establish standards for benefits related to infertility treatment. The "Family Building Act of 2001" recognizes infertility as a disease and addresses the lack of coverage for infertility treatment in group health plans by establishing standards for benefits. The "Family Building Act of 2001" requires group health plans to cover treatment for infertility, defining infertility as the inability to conceive after one year of unprotected intercourse or carry a pregnancy to live birth. The "Family Building Act of 2001" mandates group health plans to cover infertility treatments such as ovulation induction, artificial insemination, IVF, GIFT, ZIFT, ICSI, and other non-experimental treatments approved by the Secretary of Health and Human Services. The "Family Building Act of 2001" requires group health plans to cover infertility treatments, including assisted reproductive technology under certain conditions. Coverage is provided if the individual has not had success with less costly infertility treatments and has not undergone more than 4 complete oocyte retrievals. The "Family Building Act of 2001" mandates group health plans to cover assisted reproductive technology for infertility treatment under specific conditions. Coverage includes up to 6 oocyte retrievals if prior treatments have failed, performed at a qualified medical facility meeting certain standards. Assisted Reproductive Technology (ART) involves procedures with human egg and sperm to help women get pregnant. Types include in vitro fertilization, gamete intrafallopian transfer, embryo cryopreservation, and surrogate birth. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will review infertility treatment requirements within 5 years of the Family Building Act of 2001 enactment. The text chunk discusses limitations on deductibles, coinsurance, and other cost-sharing for infertility therapy under group health plans or insurance coverage. It also prohibits denial of eligibility based on infertility treatment and incentives to discourage treatment. The text chunk prohibits providers from denying infertility treatments to qualified participants, discussing treatment options, or penalizing providers for providing such treatments. It also clarifies that participants are not required to undergo infertility therapy. The text chunk addresses the notice requirement under the Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974, allows negotiation of reimbursement levels with providers, and clarifies that state laws providing greater benefits for infertility treatments are not preempted. It also includes an amendment to section 2723(c) of the Act. The text chunk introduces an ERISA amendment to Subpart B of part 7 of the Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974, adding a new section. SEC. 714. STANDARDS RELATING TO BENEFITS FOR TREATMENT OF INFERTILITY. In connection with group health plans, health insurance issuers must comply with the requirements of section 2707 of the Public Health Service Act. Health insurance issuers offering coverage must also comply with notice requirements under section 713(b) as if they were a group health plan. Section 732(a) of the Act is amended to include sections 711 and 714. Section 2753 of the Public Health Service Act establishes standards for benefits related to infertility treatment in individual health insurance plans. The provisions of section 2707 apply to health insurance coverage in the individual market. Health insurance issuers must comply with notice requirements similar to group health plans. Section 2762(b)(2) is amended to include additional sections. Effective dates apply to group health plans and insurance coverage. The amendments made by subsection (a) apply to group health plans starting on or after January 1, 2002, while the amendments made by subsection (b) apply to individual health insurance coverage on or after that date. There is an exception for group health plans under collective bargaining agreements ratified before the enactment of the Act. The last collective bargaining agreements related to the plan must terminate by January 1, 2002, or the date of enactment of this Act. Plan amendments made to conform to new requirements do not count as termination of the agreement. Section 8902 of title 5, United States Code, is amended to include coverage for infertility diagnosis and treatment in contracts providing obstetrical benefits. The amendment applies to contracts entered into or renewed at least 6 months after the enactment of this Act.
